On Linux/Mac, we should follow any precedent dotnet has already defined for assemblies (in case there's foo.dll and foo.DLL)

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: I believe we should consider not only extensions but paths.

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: Need to take in account that fat32 mounted on Linux recognizes the case-insensitiveness

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: @SteveL-MSFT Linux can mount NTFS too but I don't about case-insensitiveness.

comments.author: jeffbi
comments.body:
@iSazonov  From https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/100108/overview-of-fat,-hpfs,-and-ntfs-file-systems :

> Names preserve case, but are not case sensitive. NTFS makes no distinction of filenames based on case.

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: @jeffbi Thanks! I meant that Linux could have unpredictable implementation 😕

comments.author: joeyaiello
comments.body: @jeffbi: is this fixed by #3441? Or do we just need to take the same system-call based approach throughout more of the codebase?

comments.author: jeffbi
comments.body: @joeyaiello No, the code in #3441 is currently used only by the Copy-Item cmdlet.

title: File extension and path checks need to take into account case-sensitive file systems
